I want to be able to make this helment. Where do I start.
Spartan Helment

comments.text: There are as many ways as there are people modeling. The program I have found to be the easiest to learn is Meshmixer, and though it will take a while you can make that helmet in Meshmixer. It is a free download and only takes a few weeks to get fairly proficient with the basics. I would do it by starting with a basic primitive shape and slowly cut away the parts you don't want until you get what you do want. Focus on one side, and then you can use the mirror tool to create the other side with perfect symmetry. One thing you need to know about meshmixer, is use the make solid tool on any object before you start to edit it and before performing any bullion functions. There are lots of tutorials on youtube so take some time and learn the basics.

description.text: So I wouldn't recommend using this just yet. I'm having issues, it doesn't have enough cooling, and it doesn't exactly "drop in". This is a work in progress. It prints fairly well, I added imbeded supports on everything but the airway into the file befor I sliced it. There is a cut out photo that shows the air channels. If printed with supports it will be very difficult to clear them out. When I get a chance I'll work on it a little more. I have a few more ideas it improve it. Right now I am able to print ABS, no ninja flex yet. It seems to work better than the stock but isn't up to par with what I expected.

comments.text:
Fixed the Heat problem! Prints amazingly well! Thank you so much for this design. I had to shave off a lot of ABS to make it fit and then added a fan and everything works great.
http://imgur.com/a/UgVfX
I hot Glued the fan that came with the E3D to the plastic shroud in your design I also ripped open the back of it so the fan could blow through the heat sink I connected it to the 12v line and it works with PLA and ABS have done some 4 hour prints and everything holds up. I hot glued the fan after i had the assembly in the printer and sure to how hot glue is it is easy to remove and replace and it does not melt where it is now.
EDIT:I put some tape on the bottom of the fan to block the air flow from hitting the heating block and so it only flows trough the heat sink you should see the tape in the pictures if you look closely.

comments.text: I encountered the same issues with mine. I found the tolerances around the hot end heat sink to be to tight. This made it so it would stick up closer to the nossel. That could be why you could get it in but not take it out. I also found that the width was really tight. I'll slim it down a mill on all sides and make the tolerances a little bit louder. Should take care of it. I got mine to work regardless, and I'll add some photos. Thanks for the help!

These are two fishing lures that i designed to be used this summer. There is two size lures, one is a deep diving lure, and the other is a shallow diving lure. After you print these off you can paint them any color that you want. To set up this lure you will need a treble hook, a double eye swivel, and fishing line. Tie the treble hook to a piece of fishing string, that is at least 3 inches long. then string the line threw the lure, and tie the louse end of the fishing string on to one of the eyes of of the swivel, and tie it as tight as possible, so that it doesn't work louse.
Please comment if you find this interesting, or have any suggestions on ways to improve these lures.

This is a remix of Element18592's upload of "Unregulated Dual 18650 Box Mod (Vape)" at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1310499 .

For best quality I recommend printing it with 100% infill and maximum layer resolution (I used 0.06 mm)

List of changes:

-Overall length increased to give more working area in the top compartment
-Two versions of box- one w/ 12mm button hole, one w/ 16mm button hole
-510 connector hole increased slightly in diameter to allow connector to spin without threading into the plastic
-Inside (nut side) of the 510 connector hole has been recessed to allow the nut to thread on shorter 510 connectors

description.text:
Niftymitter is an open source short range FM transmitter based on the open source hardware design by Tetsuo Kogawa. Version 0.24 is designed to be housed within a ~1mm card body (shirt card), with a variety of options for hacking. The transmitter is tiny and handy for small scale radio broadcasts, building a distributed PA system for performances, linking your personal audio player to your car radio, or for general audio experimentation. The new version solves many of the problems in v0.22/0.23:
  • Full assembly instructions on instructables.
  • Artwork/info added on housing.
  • Stereo/mono conflict resolved - can now accommodate stereo and mono plugs.
    • KNOWN ISSUES IN v0.24:
  • circuit box slides around when switching on/off or plugging in.
  • PP3 power lead needs better access to battery tray.
    • The project's home is at openthing.org/products/niftymitter

PCB Layout v0.24 [.png - http://code.google.com/p/niftymitter/downloads/list] The PCB source is designed for etching onto copperplate, using iron on acetate (such as that described here - http://www.instructables.com/id/Mostly-easy-PCB-manufacture/) or using Michael Shorter's laser engraving method described here - http://www.instructables.com/id/Printed-Circuit-Boards-PCB-using-the-Laser-Cutte [instructables]. Circuit assembly diagram for etched PCB [.png - http://code.google.com/p/niftymitter/downloads/list] PCB layout and circuit assembly draft document [.svg - http://niftymitter.googlecode.com/files/niftymitter%20PCB%20and%20assembly%20DRAFT%20v0.24.svg] Basic Electronic Schematics, parts and assembly instructions [Tetsuo Kogawa's site - http://anarchy.translocal.jp/radio/micro/simplestTX01.jpg] General support for the electronics is on Kogawa's site here - http://anarchy.translocal.jp/radio/micro/howtosolder/howtosolder.html. Tetsuo Kogawa's site contains all the information needed to source components and assemble the electronics using his particular copperplate method. Complete Parts List [.xls - http://niftymitter.googlecode.com/files/niftymitter%20v0.24%20parts%20list.xls] Housing layouts v0.24 [.svg - http://niftymitter.googlecode.com/files/niftymitter%200.24%20housing%20layouts.svg] The layouts are designed to be laser cut and engraved, or cut and scored by hand. They are designed for ~1mm cardboard and can be assembled by folding and gluing with a quick drying adhesive such as UHU. Assembly Instructions [instructables] Assembling the Niftymitter 0.24 board - http://www.instructables.com/id/Assembling-a-Niftymitter-board-a-short-range-FM-/
Assembling a Niftymitter 0.24 - http://www.instructables.com/id/Assembling-a-Niftymitter-v024/
How to Operate Niftymitter 0.24 - http://www.instructables.com/id/How-to-Operate-Niftymitter-024/

If you have a door, say to your room, that won't close then this is for you. My room used to be a living room. Someone threw up some plywood and called it a bedroom. Except it does not have a closing locking door.

Print. Depending on how long you need your lever to be, print more or less "Lever Pieces." I used two knobs, 3 lever pieces, lever head, collar, collar minus arm, and latch.
All parts bolted together using m3 hardware, except for the knob bolt which is an m4 x 25mm. Design with those in mind as well. I drilled and glued the m4 into the knobs. I could have designed it accordingly, but forgot.

title: Space Cop badge from Red Letter Media's upcoming movie

description.text:
Update: I added a couple shots from the movie where this badge appears. Making a prop for a movie is now checked off of my bucket list :) I took the logo for Red Letter Media's upcoming movie Space Cop and made a 3d badge out of it. I cooked up a batch of these and mailed them off to RLM to use for whatever purposes they deem necessary. Be the first person on your block to have unofficial swag from an unreleased low-budget indie movie! And yes, I did ask for permission before posting this :) For more info on Space Cop, hit these links (I am not affiliated with RLM in any way, sadly): http://redlettermedia.com/space-cop-teaser-poster-and-moar-updates/ The original Space Cop trailer from several years ago:
http://redlettermedia.com/shorts/space-cop-trailer/ The Superman ripoff trailer:
http://redlettermedia.com/space-cop-teaser-trailer/

I printed these badges at .2 layer height in blue PLA from here: http://toybuilderlabs.com/pla-175/blue-pla-filament-175mm-1kgroll I printed at 100% infill to keep the infill from showing on the sides. Once printed, I masked the edges of the planet rings with masking tape and painted them with a gold-colored oil-based Sharpie. I then went over the tops of the letters S and C with the same paint. http://www.amazon.com/Sharpie-Oil-Based-Markers-Colored-1770458/dp/B003YDYO1Q/ref=pd_sim_op_2 I've found that the silver and gold paints from that set can look really amazing on 3d prints. The only catch is that the tip of the sharpie is a bit wide, so that limits the fine detail work you can do with it.

comments.text: It's a badge from the future. The future of SPACE.
comments.author: siefertma

comments.text:
I just saw them thanking you on their Twitch Stream. It sounds like one of the badges you sent was used on the car in the movie!
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RJuq_bp9gH4
Right around the 1:16:30 mark they talk about it.
comments.author: katsudon

comments.text: Yeah, I was watching that stream when it was live. If you look at Space Cop trailer #1 ( https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=28OEdVi-FPo ) , Patton Oswalt is wearing one of the badges I printed as well. So, that kinda turns this project from unofficial swag to a movie reproduction. :-D

description.text:
250 style quad copter. Designed to protect the ESC's and provide cooling from the propellers. Sturdy but nimble X-Quad, final weight around 500g. Fits 5 inch props. Made for use with motors of 27mm outer diameter or smaller.

ESC's are mounted inside the arms to offer protection. Suitable for use with flight controllers and mounting holes for a PDB.

Currently no anti-vibration mounting for a camera but this will be added in a second version when I get around to it.

Note that the Naze32 model seen in the full assembly was taken from GrabCAD and made by "The M Brothers".
Link - https://grabcad.com/library/naze-32-acro-flight-controller-1

Enjoy!

Printer:

Sunhokey 2015

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm layer height

Infill:

Arms - 50% | Others - 100%

Notes:

Some STL files are not oriented correctly in the viewer so just rotate them in your slicer so the flat parts are on the bed.

Note that there is a front and back arm. Both these parts are for the left hand side of the quad. They must be mirrored in your slicer in order to print the right hand arms.

Please print the ESC covers somewhere between 92% - 97% scale so they slot in nicely. They are best held on with tape anyway so better to be a bit on the small side.

• 6 x 35mm standoffs
  • 12 x 5mm/6mm M3 bolts (for screwing in the standoffs)
  • 10 x 20mm M3 bolts (for between the upper and lower plates including the arms)
  • 10 x M3 nuts (for the above bolts, you can use lock nuts if you wish)

  • 16 x 5mm M3 bolts (for mounting the motors to the arms, please make sure the bolts are not so far into your motors that they touch the windings this bolt length is important)

  • 4 x 12mm M3 bolts and 4 nuts (for attaching the legs if you use them)

title: AR-15 Magpul PMAG Magazine base plate - Special Forces Edition

description.text: This base plate allow the rifle to rest on the magazine when firing. I made it 2 pieces for better print quality. This is printed using ABS for strength. Glue them together using acetone and they will NOT come apart. I just use a brush to brush acetone on the bottom part, then put them together. Acetone slightly melts ABS for a stronger bond than any glue.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Yes

Med

60%

comments.text: I printed this and love it! I don't think I'll be able to test as I'm too busy to shoot the match next Saturday, but after the May one I'll run it and post a Make.  This Thing finally got me to go to Home Depot and get some acetone, glad I did.  I can't believe how strong that bond is!!! It's stronger than the lamination bond between layers!  Thank you for making a design that pushed me to discover this new fab technique.  Maybe ABS is worth the pain in the ass to print.
comments.author: IVIUPPET

comments.text: Glad I could help! I sometimes brush parts with acetone to increase the layer bond. Also, if you haven't tried it, mix acetone with about 10% filament pieces. Let it sit for a while. Shake it up. It will completely dissolve in the acetone. It makes a "slurry" rub it on your print surface so it has a glaze. Your ABS will stick to the bed perfectly! Once it cools, it will pop right off. It takes the pain out of the ass when printing with ABS. :) A heated glass bed is your friend too. I love printing with ABS now. Let me know how the competition goes. I'd love to get into 2 gun.
comments.author: IVIUPPET

comments.text: I'll definitely have to try that! I've heard of it but now that I have acetone I'll have to try.  I hate printing ABS but those material properties are worth it sometimes.
comments.author: martialmedia

remixed_from.author: DanielBull
remixed_from.title: E3Dv6 Carriage Fan Duct for NopHead Mendel90 (dibond)

title: Quick Release E3D Fan Duct for Dibond Mendel90

description.text:
A fan duct for cooling prints which can be used instead of the standard fan duct when upgrading from the J Head to an E3D hot end (in my case a v6) on a dibond NopHead Mendel90. It uses the same 60mm fan as supplied by NopHead.

This is the second version of this duct and incorporates a quick release mechanism as well as more flexible height adjustment (a common request I got on the original one here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:491316 )

I have marked it as a work in progress because even though it works great I have had issues with the release lever snapping off (ABS can be very brittle). I need to do a test print in Bridge (Nylon) to see if this solves the problem. You can repair the lever by using acetone as a glue but I have found even with the lever snapped off it still works great as it stays in place with friction (depending on your tolerances you might want add a bit of tape over the top to make it push in tighter).

NOTE: This will not fit a Sturdy Mendel90 it only fits a Dibond Mendel90. If anyone modifies it to fit please let me know and I'll include a link :)

Both the fan and bracket can be printed without supports depending on what settings and slicer you use. In fact I suggest you avoid supports as they will be a pain to remove.

I recommend using ABS or Nylon as PLA will melt this close to the extruder but any alternative high temp material should be good.

The standard 60mm fan supplied by NopHead can be used but I used shorter bolts to stop it fouling with the belt. Also I used the standard nylock nuts on the bottom but regular nuts on the top again to allow more space for the belt. The alternative (as suggested by daichiasuka in the comments on the previous fan duct) is you could flip the bolts around and recess the heads instead of the nuts, obviously this isn't as cosmetically pleasing but that may not matter depending on if you have a show printer or not :)

The bracket part slides down from the top over the two bolts which held the previous fan duct on the X carriage. You will need to slacken the bolts off far enough to get the bracket past the motor PCB bracket.

With the bracket at the midpoint of its height adjustment you should tighten the bolts. Once thats done slide the fan duct up and into the bracket from the bottom until its fully inserted. The release lever should then hold it in place. You can then adjust the height to suit.

When you want to release the fan duct, disconnect it, gently press on the release lever and pull it downwards.

title: Falla 3D - E3D Holder with Filament Cooler

description.text:
E3D Holder with Filament Cooler for Falla3d Open Source Printer

I needed to attach the E3D to my Falla3d printer, but at the same time I wanted to cool the filament. The difficulty was staying within precise space limits at the front and the sides of the extruder to avoid hitting the sides of the 20x20x20 print area. I solved it by placing the fans above the extruder (where I have all the space I want) and conveying the air around the sides of the extruder.

To facilitate printing I broke the model into:

A TOP part that contains:

  • a 40mm fan mount that conveys air to two ducts on each side of the bowden tube leading to the top of the E3D extruder
  • two 30mm fans, on each side, that convey air to two ducts to the filament
  • the four ducts slide directly into the bottom part, where they can be fixed with two screws.

A BOTTOM part that contains:

  • Designed to mount directly to the Falla3D extruder holder
  • The internal ducts go to the sides of the radiator of the E3D_V6 extruder.
  • The external ducts go to the tip for the filament. You might need to adjust the length of these with cutters, depending on how your E3D is assembled.

A BRIDGE Part that mounts to flange to lock and hold the E3D_V6 extruder with two screws.

A FIREWALL part that shields the back and bottom hot parts of the extruder, and specifically avoids the airflow for E3D radiator leaking towards the head. The firewall is mounted with two screws to the inside of the bottom part, behind the extruder. This is the only part - very simple - were ABS is necessary. All the rest can be printed with PLA and without support on most printers.

Rotation should be:

  • 135 degrees for the top part - so that the fan holders are flush against the printer bed
  • 180 degrees for the bottom part - so that the ducts go up
  • No rotation is needed for the bridge.
  • 90 degrees for the Firewall, so that the back rests on the printer bed.

title: HTC Vive controller stand and charging station

description.text:
This is a stand for the Vive's controllers.It can be used as a simple stand or as a charging station.

There are several add ins available that allow different Micro USB cables to be mounted in the stand to convert it into a charging station. If no file exists with the correct dimensions (mentioned in the file name in mm) for your USB cable, you can simply modify the included generic add in to your needs. If you want to use the micro-USB cable that comes bundled with the Vive, print the "BaseUSB_Vive" add in.

There is an awesome remix available, that allows you to magnetically attach the stand to any ferromagnetic surface: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1478739

comments.text: Printing one now, seems quite big.  What are the final printed dimensions for the base?
comments.author: Auram

comments.text:
Yes, the base station is quite large. The "two fingered" part is 198,837 mm long and 159,737 mm wide. The complete base is 87,965 mm high. I chose to make the stand's footprint that large to ensure that even if people aren't careful when inserting the controller the stand doesn't simply fall over. Other possibilities to achieve this would be to add a large weight to the bottom of the base (most ways to do that would be hard and/or expensive). Another way of securing it on a surface would be to use sticky tape (not all people want to have a permanently mounted stand for their controllers.) The base is also that high, because the interchangeable add in's will have to accept a large variety of different USB-Cables, so I measured all the cables I could find and chose the height accordingly.
If you have suggestions in which way I could improve the design, or if you want an additional stand design that uses one of the other methods of mounting described above, please just tell me and I will see what I can do.
Good luck with your print!

Second iteration of Meshbot. Now with more sensors! Front and back edge detection sensors, one front ultrasonic ping sensor, front long distance IR sensor, and four IR proximity sensors for wall detection. This bot is designed to work with the following parts:
  • Arduino Mega
  • Adafruit motor controller (or similar), a voltage controller, and a bunch of sensors
  • Pololu motors, quadrature encoder, 30T track set and sprockets
  • Radio shack 8AA battery holder
  • Radio shack 8ohm speaker
  • Radio shack lighted on/off switch
  • Radio shack red interrupt switch (for resets)
    • If anybody is interested I can provide more part details and general information. This bot is called "Meshbot" because I use the mesh features of the Xbee antenna product family to allow robot-to-robot and robot-to-operator communications.

Most parts are designed to be printed without supports or raft. The battery lid tabs are fairly small so you might want to use a raft there if build plate adhesion is a problem for you. The pictures should show the assembly process, but I'm happy to add more details. I'm working on an Arduino shield that is specific to this project, I'll release it here as soon as I can, along with the software. Here are the parts involved: 30T track set: http://www.pololu.com/catalog/product/1416
Two motors: http://www.pololu.com/catalog/product/2361
Ping sensor: http://www.amazon.com/SainSmart-Ultrasonic-Distance-Mega2560-Duemilanove/dp/B004U8TOE6/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1379275910&sr=8-1&keywords=ping+sensor
Four 10cm Sharp distance sensors: http://www.pololu.com/catalog/product/1134
Sharp 10cm distance sensor: http://www.pololu.com/catalog/product/136
Screws, #2-56 x 1/2" http://www.boltdepot.com/Product-Details.aspx?product=7655
Screws, #2-56 x 3/8" http://www.boltdepot.com/Product-Details.aspx?product=7653
Speaker: http://www.radioshack.com/product/index.jsp?productId=2062406
Motor Controller: http://www.adafruit.com/products/81
Arduino Mega: http://www.adafruit.com/products/191

title: UM2 printhead for UMO+, top and bottom part

In order to use a UM2 printhead on a Ultimaker Original+ (UMO+), the top part of the printhead needs to be rotated 90 degrees. I designed a dual extruder version, based on the original part (see github, UM2, step files).

Also included is a modified bottom part, which enables to use a thicker fan (10mm) and still guide cables through the printhead. I used a Sunon MC25100V2-000U-A99 fan which has a good airflow while being very silent.

Works like a charm, see video https://youtu.be/MSw4hv99LAA

author: cyrus

description.text: Some of my prints came brittle and fell apart between narrow layers, so I designed this to see how various changes affected small vertical layer strength. Note: I am using ABS.

Print, I used 50 infill. Try to snap off the vertical towers. If they are brittle and snap easily, experiment with the some settings.
Extra shells helped. Not too many, or the print will just look strange. Also, decreasing perimeter width over thickness helped some for me, the shells were too far apart and not touching. If you use a heated printing bed, try increasing the temperature. Mine didn't go much above 70 C right now, but I'm working on making it more effective. SolidWorks file is included in case you need it for some strange reason. You can discuss better improvements in the comments, etc.

comments.text: While obviously different types of fill will have different strengths, what would you recommend as the default fill type to test with this? My printr has settings for hollow thin walls, hollow thick walls, low fill, medium fill, high fill, and solid fill.
comments.author: Cyber_Akuma

comments.author: ftdesigns

comments.text: I was having problems with fragile connections between layers that broke too easily on narrow towers. I used this to experiment with skeinforge settings to improve it and this actually made a noticeable difference in print strength. It also helped me realize my HPB wasn't getting hot enough.

print_settings.Notes:: I used a brim with my heated bed to give a nice flat print with no curling

description.text:
Update: Coming soon! - Optional Filament guide/cleaner and possibly other modular add-on's

This is my go at designing a spool holder.

This spool holder is universal and can hold spools from 40-115mm and does not require nuts/bolts to assemble and no tools to adjust.

Assembly requires:
4x 608ZZ roller bearings
2x 10mm rubber O-Rings

Special tools:
A metal ruller or other flat metal such as a butter knife.
Cigarette lighter.

Optional:
adhesive rubber pads - I had these lying around and stuck them to the bottom of the spool holder to give it some grippy rubber feet.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I used a brim with my heated bed to give a nice flat print with no curling

Step 1:

Remove the brim by snapping it off.

Step 2:

Press the 608ZZ bearings onto the 4 posts. The should just slide straight on but may need a firm press.

Make sure they are pushed all the way down. a lip at the bottom of the post will provide 1mm clearance from the spool holder and there should be 2mm of post sticking up past the bearing.

Step 3:

Securing the bearings in place.

Place your printed parts with the bearings installed on a firm surface with the posts pointing up.

Take your Metal ruller or other flat smooth metal tool (A butter knife will work) and heat it with a cigarette lighter. You need to get it hot enough to melt the PLA 10-20seconds should be enough.

When your metal tool is hot press it down firmly on the top of one of the bearing posts and hold it there for 20-30 seconds before removing it. blowing on it will cool it faster.

Remove the tool you used, you may have to give it a little twist to break it free and the top of the bearing post should have squashed flat securing the bearing in place (see the picture in the description)

Step 4:

Take your 2 pieces of the spool holder and slide the dove tails together.

Turn the spool holder upside down so you are looking at the bottom of it.

With the smaller part of the spool holder started on the dove tail rails but sticking out so you can see the depressions for the O-Rings, take your rubber O-Rings and drop them into the depressions.

Slide the smaller part of the spool holder with the O-Rings inlace completely onto the dovetail rails. You may have to hold the O-Rings down as you do this.

The adjustable part of the Spool holder should be able to slide along the dovetail rails with some firm pressure, but not move accidentally.
I edited this file to be printed as a single piece instead of two, for added strength. Just a personal preference. Thanks to pluto77 for the original!

title: Mini Drill Press for Hobby Drill

description.text: A miniature drill press for hobby style drills. Ideal for drilling holes in PCBs. http://youtu.be/6TpeNm8IX6g The included tool mounts are designed to fit a RotaCraft RC18 Hobby Drill. It should be fairly easy to design mounts to fit other hobby drills. Update: I should have mentioned that I included the original thumb-wheel scad/stl just in case. I replaced it with the arm as I found the thumb-wheel hard to use.

You wil need the printed parts: drill_base x 1
fixed_slide x1
sliding_wedge_rack x1
rack_gear x 1
arm_mount x1
arm_knob x1 tool mounts to fit your hobby drill or: rotacraft_rc18_drill_body_mount x 1
rotacraft_rc180_drill_collar_mount x 1 M3x6 screw x 1 (To secure return spring in fixed slide)
M3x8 screw x 1 (To secure rack_gear)
M3x12 screws x 5 (To secure tool mounts)
M3x20 screw x 1 (To secure return spring to sliding wedge)
M3 washers x 6
M3 nut x 7 M8x80 threaded rod x 2 (Upright post and main shaft)
M8x110 smooth rod x 1 (Arm) M8 Nut x 5
M8 wing-nut x 1
M8 washer x 4 Return spring x 1 Fit threaded rod to base with captive M8 nut and secure with M8 nut and washer. Fit fixed slide to same rod with M8 nut and washer and captive M8 nut. Fit M3 nut into slot in rack_gear. You may have to heat the nut up and melt it into place. Fit M3x8 screw into gear. Thread M8 threaded rod into lugs on fixed_slide, adding the rack_gear. Add an M8 washer on one side, then an M8 nut followed by the arm_mount and M8 wing-nut. Tighten M3 screw in rack_gear. You may need to file a flat into the M8 threaded rod to make sure the rack gear doesn't slip. Fix tool mounts to sliding_wedge with 3 x M3 x 12 screws and 1 x M3 x 20 screw (the longer screw should be at the bottom right to attach return spring) and M3 nuts and washers. Mount tool and secure with M3x12 screws and nuts and washers. Fit sliding wedge into fixed_slide and attach return spring to the long M3 screw in the sliding wedge and attach to fixed slide with M3x6 screw into appropriate screw hole (there are 3 holes to allow adjustment). Adjust position of arm by slacking off the wing-nut, moving the arm and re-tightening wing-nut.

description.text:
Cylinder with Voronoi pattern with an inner cavity, suitable to hold a 3.5×25mm cylinder inside (3.5mm diameter, 25mm axis length). In the picture, it holds a phosphorus coated vial of tritium (which is fluorescent).

The average diameter of each arc in the Voronoi pattern is 1.5mm. At any given height (along the cylinder axis), there are at least three arcs in the pattern sustaining the structure, to avoid easy breaking.

Printer:

Ortoprinter

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Notes:

To insert the vial, print has been interrupted before closing the upper part of the cylinder to allow insertion, and then resumed. Brims can be used to help holding the object when the content is inserted.

Note on Cylinder Voronoi

To generate a correct Voronoi diagram on a UV-unwrapped cylinder, copy and shift the originating points of the Voronoi diagram on the sides of the unwrapped cylinder and use them as well to compute the diagram. The resulting diagram is periodic, yielding a perfect junction when the curves are reprojected on the cylinder.

Automatic Voronoi Cylinder with Rhino

All of this is very cumbersome, but I started with a mathematically correct idea of a Voronoi diagram on a cylinder, and it was worth trying to pursue this goal, since my "artistic" modelling skills are almost absent.

I used the trial versions of Rhinoceros 5 and T-Splines, with the aid of Grasshopper. In a second phase, I tweaked the meshes with Blender.

At first, I wrote some procedure in Grasshopper generating a Voronoi pattern on the UV-unwrapped cylinder, and re-projecting it on the cylinder. Subsequently, I tried to automatically create pipes around the pattern using T-Splines.

In a second attempt, I generated the Voronoi pattern, shrinked each Voronoi cell, created a mesh in the space between the cells, which I projected on the cylinder. I exported the mesh and thickened the junctions with Blender. Then I re-imported it in Rhinoceros, thickened it and I used it as a cage to generate T-Splines.

title: 3DS Display Stand - XL and New XL

description.text:
This is a display stand for a 3DS XL that I built after upgrading to a New 3DS Xl. My proud and storied Pikachu 3DS XL now sits on my desk, safely visible.

Models included for the New 3DS XL and for the 3DS XL. Both are currently scaled to print'n'fit without supports.

I plan on creating more versions themed to Nintendo games in the future when time arises. For now these are solid, visually appealing stands. If there's interest in a 3DS or New 3DS version, please express it in the comments and I will create such a version.

Please let me know any thoughts or opinions you might have.

Designed in Autodesk Fusion 360.

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Rostock MAX

No

No

Notes:

Prints well, looks good at .2 with 5-10% infill. No need to go overboard to get a good looking stand. Very sturdy even at low-infill.

description.text:
All the necessary tile pieces for Carcassonne's "The River II" Expansion

These were created by editing ravix's Interlocking Tiles and jfpion's River expansion.

The River II expansion splits the river into two branches and includes

"The Volcano" lake tile that acts as the Starting tile for the Dragon ('Princess and Dragon" Expansion).
"The Inn' straight road river tile. Doubles the points for the connected road. But scores nothing during endgame if the road is left incomplete.

If you do not have the expansions "Inns and Cathedrals", "Princess and the dragon" and "Traders and Builders" just play the tiles as normal.

I hope you enjoy the expansion. I plan to release more of the Expansions.

Thanks ravix and jfpion for the original pieces!
Thanks to pmeows for the "Galapagos and its Volcanos" where i sourced the volcano for the tile

Metric and Imperial T-handle sets: 2.5, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10 mm and 1/8, 3/32, 7/64, 5/32, 3/16, 7/32, 1/4", 7 of each. The top piece is the download file, to make the bottom piece delete all the interior holes leaving just the 4 perimeter holes. At the corners use 1/4"-20 threaded rod with 4 washers and nuts per rod. Cut the 4 threaded rods to 6", a Dremel and a cutoff wheel or hacksaw will do the trick. Make the ends square, and chamfer the ends so the nut threads on the rod easily. Assemble the threaded rod end on the top surface so it sits below the nut surface to ensure there are no sharp edges exposed. Use the nuts in the bottom section to level your tool holder.

remixed_from.author: mathgrrl
remixed_from.title: Customizable PolyBowl - with OpenSCAD video walkthrough

description.text:
(Psst, hey, read the Print Settings section before printing!)

I have been designing custom dice lately, and I needed a consistent way to shuffle and throw them when testing the designs for fairness. I therefore designed this dice cup using a modified version of mathgrrl's Customisable Polybowl generator. This design is nice because:

  1. You can control the thickness of the walls and base using your slicer settings.
  2. Dice get shuffled really well just from hitting the angled sides.
  3. The cup narrows at the top so that your dice are less likely to jump out during shaking.
  4. The narrow exit also tends to make the dice hit each other as they exit, making things even more random!

If you use this dice cup by holding it vertically and shaking it, you can shuffle 4 dice very efficiently. If you put your hand over the opening and shake it upside-down, you can shuffle up to 10.

(The numbered dice in the photo are my d0-5 and d1-6, you can get them here.)

Infill:

NONE, ZERO, NO INFILL

Notes:

You'll notice that this object is solid, and that's because you are supposed to control its thicknesses in your slicer. Set infill and top layers to 0, and bottom layers and perimeters to whatever you like. You can also enable vase mode if you like.

26 Mar 2016

comments.text: There are some issues with printing this upright with supports that I see.  Too little contact area with the clip part and the support tower so it wobbles as the print head makes contact.  Only way I see to get a good print out of it is to print it upside down with "supports everywhere" option enabled.  If the bottom of the clip were flattened out some it may work a little better for printing upright. Retention is good though for the knife in the sheath part.

I'm not sure what you mean by "lip back" but if you are talking about the radii on all edges, they are there to protect my tender flesh from sharp edges.  If you want to flatten either surface just drop the part a small amount in the "Z" axis (.5mm) or use a raft.

comments.text: The piece that your phone clips into is risen 1.5 mm off the print surface and the handlebar piece is set at 0.00mm offest. Since both objects are recognized as one single piece in the download, the printer begins by only making the handle bar piece for 1.5 mm then moves to the phone holder and starts printing it in mid air (1.5mm high). my suggestion is to separate these pieces into 2 files so you can zero both out on the bed. or go back into CAD and drop the phone holder 1.5mm so both prints start at 0.00 offest.

author: 3DForHomeWorking

description.text:
Watch this video for more information and to see the full tree: https://youtu.be/b42-JUGWQ7A :)

Who needs a tree specifically for Christmas when you can just redecorate it year round! That's exactly what I'm doing, we've done Christmas, Valentine's Day and now it's time for Easter!

I created some flat ornaments in the shape of rabbits, chicks, and eggs with a couple different patterns on them. There are certain raised areas on them to make them easier and hopefully more fun to paint. These all have little loops on the top that you can either put string though or use the metal hangers that most ornaments come with.

I also created some more light toppers. These are just transparent filament caps that slide on to the top of your existing string lights that normally go around trees and on houses. The cylinder shaped ones are just to change the color of the light. I used transparent green and transparent blue from Hatchbox for these. There are also egg shaped toppers that add a little extra to the tree and draw people's attention.

Filament I used:
Hatchbox Pink PLA: http://amzn.to/1LNtSuL
Hatchbox Transparent Blue PLA: http://amzn.to/25oK24e
Hatchbox Transparent Green PLA: http://amzn.to/22LlGiS

Print Settings:
Layer Height: 0.3mm
Infill: 10% (could be 0% for the light toppers)

author: UrbanAtWork

title: Davinci Bed Level Screw (No nuts required)

description.text: Basically i took some other ideas off of thingiverse and just customized them because i didn't have any M3 nuts on hand. I printed these off in PETG plastic, so if you print them in ABS you may have to print at a higher or lower size percentage to account for shrinkage as PETG is very low shrinkage. Just print them off, and then take the screw dial off your print bed and press (maybe use a hammer and punch gently) them into the hole until it bottoms out and screw them back on! Very simple and nice to use. I uploaded the STL and the solidworks file if anybody feels they'd like to customize or tweak.

description.text:
I made this in TinkerCad from the Gantry Cover by NAVG8R, It is for 40mm Extruder and Cooling Fans. You may have to change the size if it does not work on your fan. For the cooler some sanding on the bottom is needed to provide clearance over your print.

It is held on simply by tension of the part. I added some tape to the top of the inside to tighten the fit so they dont fall off easily.

author: EquinsuOcha

title: HICTOP Prusa i3 MKS Base V1.3  board cover.

description.text: This is a cover for the motherboard on the HICTOP Prusa i3. Supposedly it's an MKS Base V1.3. I couldn't find anything already made for this particular version. Make sure your board has all the power plugins together. A similar model has the main power separated from the rest, and won't work with this cover. One of the corners is fragile on its own, but is fine once it's screwed to the board. Even if it breaks off, you can still screw it in place separately just fine. If you make it leave me feedback in the comments please!
Designed in AutoCAD. printed a lot of prototypes till I got the spacing just right.

comments.text: Stepper motor drivers get quite hot, surely this will insulate them to the point of getting hotter. Does anyone have any problems with overheating?
comments.author: Laurence3D

comments.text: Agreed-  I have this board and event installed heat sinks over top of the driver chips.  Not a good idea to seal them in without proper ventilation.
comments.author: Laurence3D

comments.text: The model looks different to the one you printed. the 2 bottom corner holes are countersunk on your printed version but not the model, noticed it in SketchUp when designing additional wire guides to be printed in TPU.
comments.author: dissidify

comments.text: I'm not entirely sure what you mean, but the bottom screw holes on my printed version do look different than the stl model, this was a flaw in my print. The wall got too thin and my machine decided to skip over it. Probably something I could fix by tweaking some settings, but it didn't affect its usage so I just kept it that way.
Great work! this is going on my new Build
comments.author: CT_FPV

comments.text: Thanks! Let me know if it fit your board alright!
comments.author: CT_FPV
